title: Social Media: Can social media replace mainstream media? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think it already has: Isn’t anyone honest anymore? Who can we turn to for “truth” . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . CNN BUSTED spreading huge Clinton lie . . . . . . . . . . . . . . MARCH 3, 2017 CNN’s Don Lemon was just caught spreading another lie about failed Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton — and this whopper is TRULY unbelievable. Lemon — ranked in 2014 as one of the America’s worst journalists by Columbia University — went on the attack against Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Wednesday evening. Lemon claimed Sessions needed to step aside immediately following the over-hyped media frenzy regarding two meetings Sessions had with a Russian ambassador while working as a senator. The controversial CNN anchor then incorrectly compared the situation to the investigation into Hillary’s emails — and said that former President Barack Obama’s administration handled things differently. “Loretta Lynch recused herself from any decision regarding Hillary Clinton because of that meeting of Hillary Clinton and Loretta Lynch, who was attorney general at the time, on the tarmac,” Lemon said during a discussion on Sessions. Lemon was referring to Bill Clinton’s meeting, a secret discussion that caused a furious response from the right and demands for Lynch to resign. “The CNN panel, which included the network’s chief political correspondent, Dana Bash, CNN executive editor Mark Preston and CNN contributor Margaret Hoover, nodded along at first, and they continued their discussion of the Sessions controversy,” The Washington Examiner reported. But it wasn’t true. Lynch refused to recuse herself from the investigation, either –despite bipartisan pressure to do so. Lemon should know better… that was less than one year ago, in July 2016! You can see the exchange below — President Donald Trump had previously said that Lemon’s nightly news show “is almost exclusive anti-Trump” and has repeatedly branded CNN as “very fake news.” Eventually Bash did correct Lemon, who (predictably) failed to apologize or correct himself. But not before the damage was done, and more “fake news” was already spread. They just can’t help themselves, can they? — The Horn editorial team

I think you need to rephrase your question. You’re not really taking about social media replacing main stream media. You’re talking about social media acting as a distribution agent for main stream media. There is a big difference in scope between the two. That distribution switch could eventually happen and to an extent it already has. Just about every major media outlet has a Facebook and/or Twitter account and a web page. The web page is interactive for most of them. But a complete changeover will take a while because there are still a lot of people out there who can’t afford an internet connection. There are also a lot of people who don’t have smart phones, or tablets, or even desktops. And when it does happen I don’t see any major media outlet giving complete control of access to someone else. They will keep their own web sites, etc. As far as replacing main stream media, the small paper I worked at had a daily circulation of about 50K with a Sunday circulation of about 85K and we had approximately 200 full time editors, reporters, photographers, and graphic artists in the newsroom. Then you had subscriptions to wire services and syndicated columns, etc. This is for one little local paper. Extrapolate the number of people you would need to cover the world like Facebook does. There is phenomenal overhead in a news gathering organization. I don’t think that social media is quite ready for this challenge.
